    [ -f "$file" ] || continue
    unzip "$file" -d "${file%%.zip}"
done

so_44846638: Unzip all gz files in all subdirectories in the terminal
so_12945111: Unzip fails when specifying keyword
Top-3 Scripts:
so_44846638: cd theparentdir && gzip -d $(find ./ -type f -name '*.gz')

cd theparentdir && gzip $(find ./ -type f -name '*.csv')

cd theparentdir && find ./ -type f -name '*.gz' -exec gzip -d '{}' '+'

cd theparentdir && find ./ -type f -name '*.csv' -exec gzip '{}' '+'

so_12945111: # Unzip can interpret wildcards itself instead of the shell
# if you put them in quotes.
unzip -o '*.zip' '*PSU*' -d psutmp/

# If all of the zip files are in one directory, no need for find.
for i in *.zip; do unzip -o "$i" '*PSU*' -d psutmp/; done

# "find -exec" is a nice alternative to "for i in `find`".
find . -name '*.zip' -exec unzip -o {} '*PSU*' -d psutmp/ \;

ul_321683: for d in *.zip
do
  dir=/home/usrname/anotherdir/zip${d%%.zip}
  unzip -d "$dir" "$d"
done
